column5: Examples include buzz; splash; and pop

column3: What is a preposition?
column4: A word that shows the relationship between a noun and other words in a sentence
column5: Examples include in; on; under; and beside

column3: What is a homonym?
column4: Words that sound the same but have different meanings
column5: Examples include their/there/they're

column3: What is the main difference between a biography and an autobiography?
column4: A biography is written by someone else; an autobiography is written by the subject themselves
column5: Both are accounts of a person's life

column3: What is foreshadowing?
column4: A literary device where the author gives hints about what will happen later in the story
column5: Creates anticipation and tension

column3: When did World War I begin?
column5: Triggered by the assassination of Archduke Franz Ferdinand

column3: Who was the first European explorer to reach Australia?
column5: Dutch navigator who landed in 1606

column3: What was the name of the policy that removed Aboriginal children from their families?
column5: Government policy from early 1900s to 1970s

column3: When did Federation occur in Australia?
column5: Six colonies became one nation

column3: Who was the first Prime Minister of Australia?
column5: Served from 1901 to 1903

column3: What treaty ended World War I?
column5: Signed in 1919

column3: Who led the Russian Revolution in 1917?
column5: Founded the Soviet Union

column3: What was the Renaissance?
column4: A period of cultural rebirth and renewed interest in classical learning
column5: Began in Italy in the 14th century

column3: Who was Captain James Cook?
column4: British explorer who charted the east coast of Australia
column5: Arrived at Botany Bay in 1770

column3: What was the Cold War?
column4: A period of geopolitical tension between the United States and the Soviet Union
column5: Lasted from 1947 to 1991

column3: What was the Industrial Revolution?
column4: A period of transition to new manufacturing processes
column5: Began in Britain in the late 18th century

column3: Who were the ANZACs?
column4: Australian and New Zealand Army Corps who fought in World War I
column5: Remembered for their role in the Gallipoli Campaign

column3: What was the Great Depression?
column4: A severe worldwide economic depression in the 1930s
column5: Began with the U.S. stock market crash of 1929

column3: Who was the first woman to become a member of Australian Parliament?
column5: Elected to Western Australian Legislative Assembly in 1921

column3: What is the significance of the Eureka Stockade?
column4: A rebellion of gold miners against colonial authority
column5: Occurred in Ballarat in 1854

column3: When did Captain Arthur Phillip arrive with the First Fleet?
column5: Established the first European settlement in Australia

column3: What was the White Australia Policy?
column4: Immigration restriction policies favoring European immigrants
column5: Officially abolished in 1973

column3: Who was Ned Kelly?
column5: Known for his homemade suit of armor

column3: What year did women gain the right to vote in Federal elections in Australia?
column5: Australia was among the first countries to grant women this right

column3: What is the capital city of Australia?
column5: Planned city designed by Walter Burley Griffin

column3: Which is the largest ocean on Earth?
column5: Covers more than 30% of Earth's surface

column3: What is the name of the largest desert in Australia?
column5: Spans Western Australia and South Australia

column3: What is a peninsula?
column4: A piece of land almost surrounded by water
column5: Connected to the mainland on one side

column3: What are the three main types of rock?
column5: Classified based on how they form

column3: What is the capital of Japan?
column5: Located on the island of Honshu

column3: What is erosion?
column4: The process of wearing away soil and rock by water; wind; or ice
column5: Changes the landscape over time

column3: What is the largest coral reef system in the world?
column5: Located off the coast of Queensland

column3: What causes tsunamis?
column4: Underwater earthquakes; volcanic eruptions; or landslides
column5: Creates powerful ocean waves

column3: What is the driest inhabited continent?
column5: Much of the continent is desert or semi-arid

column3: What is the name of the line that divides the Earth into Northern and Southern Hemispheres?
column5: 0 degrees latitude

column3: What is the capital of New South Wales?
column5: Australia's largest city

column3: What is the difference between weather and climate?
column4: Weather is short-term conditions; climate is the average weather pattern over a long period
column5: Climate describes what's expected; weather describes what happens

column3: Which mountain range runs along Australia's east coast?
column5: Extends from Queensland to Victoria

column3: What is the primary cause of the greenhouse effect?
column4: Gases in the atmosphere trapping heat
column5: Carbon dioxide is a major greenhouse gas

column3: What is a topographic map?
column4: A map showing physical features of the land
column5: Uses contour lines to show elevation

column3: What is the name of the sea between Australia and New Zealand?
column5: Named after Dutch explorer Abel Tasman

column3: What are the three main layers of the Earth?
column5: The core has inner and outer parts

column3: What is the longest river in Australia?
column5: Flows through New South Wales; Victoria; and South Australia
